subject: PRE-MARKET SOUTH KOREAN  NEWS: Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) is pushing to list its ICT affiliate; Japanese markets are closed for Labour Thanksgiving Day
content:
JAPAN

Nissan (7201 JT)
- Co. confirmed it has dismissed Ghosn via unanimous decision as well as Representative Director Kelly. (Newswires)

Nitori Holdings (9843 JT)
- Co. November same store sales rose 1.3% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News
- Japan Cabinet Office November Monthly Economic Report maintained its overall economic assessment in which it stated that the economy is recovering at a moderate pace. (Newswires)


SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. is pushing to list its ICT service provider affiliate Hyundai AutoEver Corp. (Yonhap)

Other News
- North Korea appear to be expanding operations at its main nuclear site, according to the IAEA. (Nikkei)
- South Korean Parliament will hold a hearing regarding Finance Minister nominee on December 4th. (Newswires)

subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: BHP (BHP AT) is to fight a GBP 5bln lawsuit filed in UK related to the Samarco dam failure
content:
BHP (BHP AT)
- Co. is to fight a GBP 5bln lawsuit filed in UK related to the Samarco dam failure. (AFR)

Bluescope Steel (BSL AT)
- Co. affirmed H1 FY2019 guidance and said it is seeing continued strength of demand in major markets. (Newswires)

Brickworks (BKW AT)
- Co. will acquire US-based brickmaker Gren-Gray for AUD 151mln. (Newswires)

Macquarie (MQG AT)
- Co. CEO appeared at the banking royal commission and was said to have emerged unscathed and with the Co.’s reputation enhanced. (Newswires)

Village Roadshow (VRL AT)
- Co. says current trading is encouraging and that it may resume dividend at end-FY2019 if it is appropriate. (Newswires)

subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Japanese Nikkei Manufacturing PMI, Singapore and Malaysia CPI data, Japan and India market closures
US government is said to ask foreign allies to stop using Huawei
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China wants to make a deal on trade "very badly" and if we can make a deal we will. (Newswires)

China responded to the recent US Treasury report in which it labelled the accusation of unfair trade practices as groundless and totally unacceptable, while it added that it hopes US drops rhetoric and behaviour that are damaging to relations. (Newswires)
 

UK

UK PM May announced that the text of declaration was agreed with the EU in which the text has explicit reference to development of independent trade policy for the UK. PM May added that the deal ends free movement and protects the union, while she added that preparatory work on alternative arrangements to avoid the backstop would begin before we leave. PM May also commented that this deal delivers on the vote of the referendum, while she is confident on being able to agree a deal that delivers for whole of the UK including Gibraltar. (Newswires)

UK Government Official said UK has no further demands for further Brexit negotiations ahead of the Sunday summit and said there will be no second referendum as long as May remains PM. (Newswires) In related news, cabinet source said UK PM May told ministers that Gibraltar was "more of an issue than expected" but is confident it can be resolved. (FT)

EU will monitor UK environment rules and wants reciprocal fishing access and quotas agreed before transition ends. Empty space left for text on Gibraltar, according to EU27 Leaders' draft notes. (Newswires)

Spanish PM Sanchez said position with UK remain far away and that Spain will veto Brexit deal if there are no changes. (Newswires)

Tory Brexiteer Iain Duncan Smith confirmed that the Brexit deal will be killed off by him and his Brexiteer colleagues in Parliament and is said to dismiss PM May's efforts to adopt a tech solution to the Irish border problem implying it is meaningless, according to ITV’s Peston. (Twitter)

BuzzFeed senior political correspondent suggested that over 50% of Tory backbenchers have publicly indicated they will not vote for the deal. (Newswires)

Tory MPs in Scotland are absolutely furious at commitment to a 'new fisheries agreement' on quotas and access to waters as they see it as abandoning post-Brexit sovereignty, according to The Telegraph political editor. (Twitter)

BoE’s Saunders reiterated that implications on monetary policy from different Brexit outcomes could go either way and that policy stance would need to return to something similar to neutral sooner than curve implies in the event of a smooth Brexit. (Newswires)


EU

ECB Minutes stated members considered that the uncertainties related to global factors remained prominent and the risks related to the external environment were assessed to be tilted to the downside. The minutes also noted that it had to be emphasised that policy remained on steady track in line with market expectations and previous decisions, while policymakers generally agreed that data, while weaker than expected, remained consistent with expansion and gradually rising inflation pressures. (Newswires)

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said we are at a maturing economic cycle, that stock markets are fairly high and that there could be corrections to come but added stock market corrections don't worry us from a monetary policy perspective. (Newswires)

ECB's Praet said downside risks have increased but at this stage we still think the picture remains broadly balanced, while he added that core inflation at around 1% are not enough to reach our aim in sustained manner. Praet added that he is confident that underlying inflation pressures are rising but it will take time and it requires monetary policy to remain accommodative. Praet also commented it is too soon to decide new TLTRO or adjustments in key rates. (Newswires)

Italy PM Conte said he will ask for a long time-frame to implement EU requests on the budget and commented that EU demands to cut the deficit are not compatible with the state of the economy. Separately, there were comments from Italy Deputy PM Salvini that he has "no more patience" with EU commissioner Moscovici and accused him of insulting Italy, while Italy's Economy Minister Tria said that there will be "new elements" regarding the budget once Commission talks start. (Newswires)

FX

South African Reserve Bank hiked Repo Rate by 25bps to 6.75% vs. expectations for rates to be kept unchanged at 6.50%. The vote was split on rate decision with 3 voting to hold and 3 voting for a 25bps hike. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said Saudi oil production is currently greater than in the past and above 10.7mln BPD, while he had also commented that oil in January will be lower and Saudi is to respond to demand to cool off anxiety (Newswires)
 

US

US President Trump has authorised US troops to use lethal force at the Mexican border, while Trump also threatened a government shutdown in December over border security. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

US markets were closed for Thanksgiving.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 22nd November 2018: Trump says China wants to make a deal; UK/EU reach Brexit political declaration agreement
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

THANKSGIVING WRAP – 22nd November 2018: Trump says China wants to make a deal; UK/EU reach Brexit political declaration agreement

* REAR-VIEW: EU and UK negotiators struck agreement on political declaration, Trump says China wants deal very badly, ECB Minutes highlight risks to external environment tilted to downside, SARB hiked repo rate by 25bps, BoE’s Haldane and Saunders Speaking, ECB’s Mersch to speak.

* AHEAD: German GDP, Eurozone PMIs, Canadian CPI, Early US market closures & Japan away on holiday.

* NOTE: Early Market Closures due to Thanksgiving: Thursday the desk will operate a normal service on Thursday until 1800GMT/1200CST, upon which the desk will close and then re-open later at 2200GMT/1600CST for the beginning on the Asia-Pacific session given the US market closures. Friday the desk will operate a normal service on Friday until 1845GMT/1245CST, upon which the desk will close given the US market closures.

 

* BREXIT: The European Commission and British negotiators have struck an agreement on the text of their political declaration for future EU-UK ties post-Brexit. European Council President Tusk said the text has been agreed at the negotiators level and agreed in principle at political level, subject to the endorsement of the Leaders” ahead of Sunday's summit. The draft document outlined that the EU and UK are determined to replace the backstop in the future, the EU are to recognise the UK's independent trade practice and the transition period can be extended once for a maximum of two years with a joint decision to be taken before 1st July 2020. In briefing the parliament, UK PM May added that the text makes explicit reference to development of independent trade policy for the UK, it ends free movement and protects the union while it would imply leaving the common agricultural policy and common fisheries policy; she also made clear that to the Spanish PM that Gibraltar's British sovereignty must be protected. Elsewhere, UK PM May’s spokesperson noted that no final deal can be agreed without the approval of the EU council on Sunday. Sources suggested that the EU 27 leaders aim to endorse separate declaration on Sunday along with Brexit package to cover fisheries, environmental standards and Gibraltar given that the issues do not appear to be resolved. Separately, Northern Ireland DUP Lawmaker Donaldson if the UK wants DUP support it needs to see the end of the backstop while some reports suggested that over 50% of Tory backbenchers have publicly indicated they will not vote for the deal.

* ITALY: There were mixed opinions on Thursday over whether the government is open to negotiations with the EU over the resubmitted 2019 budget plan as Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio continue to appear reluctant to make any adjustments. In comments, Salvini stressed the country will not backtrack on the budget law noting that the only thing the EU cannot ask Italy is to change is the unwinding of the pension reform and accused EU commissioner Moscovici of insulting Italy; PM Conte stated EU demands to cut the deficit aren't compatible with the state of the economy and he will ask for a long time-frame to implement EU requests on the budget; Di Maio ruled out any changes to the plan prior to EU elections while remaining open for discussion with the EU. Eurosceptic European Affairs Minister Savona was also said to be strongly in favour of amending the budget plan, voices later denied. In related news, Italian President Mattarella urged PM Conte to reach a deal with European Commission President Juncker.

* TRADE: US President Trump said that China wants to make a deal on trade "very badly" and if we can make a deal we will. Elsewhere, Chinese Commerce Ministry said that China and US work teams remain in close contact to implement mutual understandings achieved by the countries' leaders; China is deeply concerned about US new section 301 report update

* ECB MINUTES: In-fitting with the release itself, the account of the October meeting failed to instigate much in the way of price action. The minutes saw some members concerned “that the uncertainties related to global factors remained prominent, and the risks related to the external environment were assessed to be tilted to the downside”. This wasn’t necessarily too surprising for markets as the ECB bulletin suggested that this was the case despite the ECB maintaining their language at the October announcement that risks to the Euro Area economy itself are broadly balanced. Nonetheless, the comment served as a timely reminder ahead of the December meeting that the Bank could be forced reassess their view of the domestic economy. Recent commentary from policymakers has helped highlight this issue with ECB’s Draghi early this month stating that “the current slowdown has raised questions about the strength of the growth outlook, and we're seeing a temporary soft patch”. The question ahead of December is now whether or not a ‘temporary’ soft patch will be enough to derail policymakers in their assessment of the Euro area and if that could impact the Bank’s plan to lift rates in 2019; something which markets are eager to pin the bank down on. Elsewhere, the only reference to TLTRO’s was that “some TLTRO maturities would fall below 1yr, which could impact banks' liquidity position”, however, this offered little insight into whether or not the Bank will opt to launch a further round of TLTROs next year.

* ECB: ECB's Praet said he is confident that underlying inflation pressures are rising but it will time and it requires monetary policy to remain accommodative; he noted that downside risks have increased but at this stage the picture remains broadly balanced. Core inflation at around 1% is enough to reach our aim in sustained manner while he believes it is too early to decide on new TLTRO now and early adjustments to key interest rates and their constellation.

 * SARB: The central bank hiked its Repo rate by 25bps to 6.75% at its meeting on Thursday; the vote was split on the decision with 3 members voting to hold rates at 6.50% and 3 pushing  for a 25bps hike. The decision was based on the MPC view that the rising inflation trajectory which, while remaining within target range, continues to deviate from the mid-point of target range; the central bank will continue to assess risks to the longer term inflation outlook to be on the upside. Additionally, the MPC noted that near-term outlook on inflation has improved but longer term risks still remain as growth is subdued and lacking any pressure on CPI driven by demand, TD Securities pointed out. Nonetheless, the SARB’s model still projects an increase in headline inflation, even if slower than the September forecasts, with CPI seen averaging 4.7% in 2018 (September forecast 4.8%) and averaging 5.5% in 2019 (September forecast 5.7%). Looking ahead, Governor Kganyago announced that the implied path model shows 4 rate hikes of 25bps to 7.5% by end of 2020 suggesting a very gradual pace of hiking, Informa argued, adding that “this may limit ZAR gains as it is clear the MPC has acted now to avoid deeper hikes down the line”.

* GBP: Sterling has soared to the top of the G10 rankings, albeit rather belatedly, as news broke and details emerged on the political declaration for future ties between the UK and EU reached by the Brexit negotiators in advance of Sunday’s summit. Cable took a while to clear 1.2800, but then gathered pace when 1.2850 was surpassed and only lost momentum through 1.2900 after failing to breach resistance just above that big figure convincingly. Similarly, EURGBP appeared somewhat reluctant to take out 0.8900, but when the cross broke below the round number selling accelerated to just under 0.8850, and before the Pound ran in to resistance, profit taking and the realisation that euphoria could be overdone or at least premature given ratification by EU leaders and UK Parliament is still needed.

* EUR: The single currency has been stabilising amid thin trading conditions, and has brushed off the latest contentious commentary out of Italy after the EU rejected its 2019 budget. However, clearly the Italians and Europeans are maintaining channels of dialogue, helping to keep the euro in positive territory, supported also by Brexit headlines too. There was little reaction after the publication of the ECB’s latest meeting minutes, where it flagged uncertainty around global factors, noting that external environment were judged to be to the downside, while there were also comments made that TLTRO maturities falling beneath one year could impact banks’ liquidity positions. As we go to print, the EUR is consolidating around 1.14.

* USD: The buck was mixed on Thanksgiving, with US players out for the market holiday. Haven FX JPY and CHF were sold, the latter on optimism around Brexit. The DXY itself trades negative, with increasing noises about growth concerns weighing on the greenback after a few weak data points – next week’s docket of Fed speakers (including Powell) and FOMC minutes may provide a catalyst, after the cautious tone expressed by some Fed speakers after the last fortnight (Clarida).

* ZAR: Despite a split vote, the SARB rate hike lifted the Rand, in thing, holiday trading conditions, seeing USDZAR print a low of the day around 13.73. Technicians have suggested that a second close beneath the 14.00 level would be significant, and potentially open the door to the 13.30 region.

subject: South Korea and Japan are reportedly unlikely to purchase Iranian oil in January
PRIMER: ECB October Minutes due to be released Thursday 22nd November at 1230GMT/0630CST
content: As has been the case for several months now, October’s ECB policy announcement saw little in the way of fireworks after the central bank opted to maintain their current policy settings before unwinding their PSPP at the end of the year. Heading into the release, analysts speculated over whether recent developments in the Eurozone economy would force the hand of the governing council to suggest that risks surrounding growth are ‘tilted to the downside’. However, the Bank refrained from potentially disturbing markets before the conclusion of its QE programme and maintained its ‘broadly balanced’ viewpoint. That said, any debate around this matter will be closely watched by the market: if there are any indications that it was a close decision to stick to their current assessment, markets could potentially expect an adjustment in the coming months if economic conditions fail to improve. Elsewhere, Draghi was quick to bat-away any questions on capital key recalculations, an extension to QE and what the Bank would do if the economic situation deteriorates by stating that they were not discussed. As such, the account of the meeting might be light in terms of clues about the Bank’s future path of monetary policy. Furthermore, investors will likely be interested in any debate at the meeting regarding policymakers’ views on the Italian situation. However, commentary will likely echo remarks made by Draghi who, at the time, suggested that Italy should respect EU rules. Finally, market participants will also be looking out for any discussions on a potential further round of TLTRO’s after speculation the Bank could embark on measures to help support domestic banks in 2019 as its PSPP draws to a close. However, such discussions may not necessarily feature in the October account after source reports at the beginning of November suggested the topic is not an urgent one at the ECB and may not feature in discussions at the Dec meeting.

subject: Italian Deputy PM Di Maio rules out changes to the Italian budget prior to EU elections and they won't got over 2.4% deficit/GDP target in 2019
RANsquawk EU Mid Session: FTSE 100 pounded as draft PD details boosts GBP - 22nd November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities are lower across the board (Eurostoxx 50 -0.8%) as risk sentiment in the region deteriorates alongside lower liquidity with US participants away on Thanksgiving Holiday. Broad-based losses are experienced across major European bourses while UK’s FTSE 100 (-1.4%) underperforms on currency effects as the details of the draft Brexit political declaration emerged. UK banks have received a boost after the draft PD stated that the EU foresees equivalence for UK banks and as a result, Barclays (+0.3%), RBS (+1.9%) and Lloyds Banking Group (-0.3%) spiked to session highs.

Elsewhere, Italy’s FTSE MIB (-0.8%) is lower amid conflicting press reports in Italian politics, with the latest news stating that Italian Deputy PM Salvini will not backtrack on the budget, after it was rejected by the European Commission yesterday.

Sectors are red across the board with underperformance in material names amid a decline in base metal prices amid the risk averse tone.  In terms of individual movers, Altice (-13.3%) rests at the foot of the Stoxx 600 after revenues missed expectations, while investors keep an eye on Renault shares (-1.3%) with the Nissan board meeting underway to discuss the ousting of Nissan’s chairman Ghosn after his arrest earlier this week due to alleged financial misconduct.   

FX

NZD/AUD - The marked outliers and major underperformers, with the Kiwi back below 0.6800 and Aud under 0.7250 as the cross pivots the 1.0650 level. Nothing really new in terms of NZ or Aussie specific catalysts for the relatively sharp retreats from recent highs, although ANZ predicted a 20% slump in property prices in Melbourne and Sydney overnight, but as usual the high-beta commodity currencies are more responsive to swings in overall sentiment and aversion is rearing its head again after faint respite ahead of the US Thanksgiving break.

EUR/JPY/CHF/GBP/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback in thin US holiday trade, with the single currency remaining close to the 1.1400 handle and its 100 HMA (1.1404) amidst more token or half-hearted murmurings from Rome about 2019 budget in an effort to appease the EU and avoid punitive deficit measures, which are hampering upside attempts along with decent option expiry interest (1.1 bn between 1.1430-40). Usd/Jpy is pivoting 113.00 on the aforementioned resumption of risk-off positioning/flows, which is also supporting the Franc to a degree within a 0.9930-50 range. Elsewhere, Cable has rebounded firmly over 1.2800, through 1.2850 and just shy of 1.2900+ resistance, while Eur/Gbp is back below 0.8900 and eyeing 0.8850 bids/support following reports that EU and UK negotiators have now reached an accord on the political declaration for post-Brexit relations. Meanwhile, the Loonie is holding up relatively well against the backdrop of retreating crude prices ahead of a speech from BoC’s Wilkins.

NOK/SEK - The Scandi crowns are not immune from the loss of risk appetite and downturn in oil, with Eur/Nok up above 9.7500 and Eur/Sek touching 10.3300 after Riksbank commentary courtesy of Skingsley downplaying minor deviations and fluctuations in the rate of inflation, but keeping policy intentions under wraps awaiting more data before the December meeting (including and pivotally the next Swedish CPI report on December 12th).

FIXED INCOME

The proof remains very much in the pudding and pending Parliament approval assuming EU leaders sign off on the draft this Sunday, but for now at least the markets are giving the draft declaration their benefit of doubt. Indeed, the 10 year UK bond has reversed markedly, albeit rather belatedly from a minor new Liffe high of 123.19 to a fresh and deeper 122.58 trough (-41 ticks), with Bunds retreating in sympathy from 160.87 to retest the early 160.63 base vs Wednesday’s 160.58 close and US Treasuries also acknowledging the turnaround, but marginally in holiday-thinned conditions.

COMMODITIES 

WTI (-1.6%) and Brent (-1.3%) resumed their decline amid the downbeat sentiment across the market, with some traders also attributing the recent fall to technical factors amid thin liquidity in the complex. Elsewhere, gold (+0.2%) is outperforming given the softer USD and safe-haven demand, while copper (-0.8%) underperforms amid the sour risk tone fused with concerns over global economic growth slowdown. Finally, China’s steel sector is flirting with the on the fence between a bear market, with prices declining almost 20% in the last three months as record production meets concerns of slower global growth and trade disputes.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures gleaning some bullish momentum after indecisive start
content: UK debt and STIRs are grinding higher in line with core counterparts as risk sentiment sours somewhat via a downturn in EU equites and renewed weakness in BTPs, which has lifted Bunds to a marginal new Eurex peak at 160.83 (+1/4 point), just above Wednesday’s intraday high. Back to Liffe, Gilts just topped out at 123.18 vs yesterday’s 122.99 close having kicked off below parity at 122.92, while the 3 month strip is now 1-2 ticks ahead vs -1 tick here and there earlier. Looking ahead, no UK data due, but for those still around later on Thanksgiving, BoE’s Haldane and Saunders are slated to appear at separate events, while there is always the potential for more Brexit headlines alongside Italian budget exchanges.

subject: China exempts taxes on oversea bond investments for three years
Bunds: some early decoupling before further upside consolidation
content: A light and modestly firm start to Thursday’s Eurex session for the 10 year German debt future, but hardly any additional traction from an initial 160.70 print as the core bond fizzled out at 160.71 vs yesterday’s 160.58 close and then drifted down to 160.63 before gradually grinding higher again and just eclipsing the early peak, at 160.73. Meanwhile, Italian BTPs are meandering between 121.85-42 vs their previous 121.45 settlement price amidst completely mixed messages, at least according to latest press reports, from Government officials over potential adjustments to the 2019 budget after official EU condemnation on Wednesday. Ahead, some scope for a bit more activity via the ECB minutes ahead of flash consumer confidence, but of course no US input given the Thanksgiving holiday.

BBVA (BBVA SM) – Co. are looking for EUR 900mln to offload their Mexican headquarters, according to sources. (Newswires)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Co. sees FY adj. operating cash flow in GBP 2.1-2.3bln range and are to maintain dividend. Co. expects to achieve 2018 group targets. (Newswires)

Housing names – FCA has proposed to introduce a rent-to-own sector price cap, effective 1st April and subject to consultation. (Sky News)

Severn Trent (SVT LN) – HY revenue +3.6% to GBP 881.5mln. HY group reported PBIT +1.4% GBP 299.1mln. Co. says HY OIDS are in line with expectations. (Newswires)

Intu (INTU LN) – Consortium of Peel Group, Olayan Group and Brookfield Properties have until 30th Nov to make a firm offer for the Co. Consortium has confirmed that nothing has arisen from due diligence which would have lead to a change in proposal. (Newswires)

FERGUSON (FERG LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT CANACCORD GENUITY

subject: Italy's ruling League party are open to changing budget law but 5SM are against it; according to Il Messaggero
DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

22nd November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities were mixed as the region struggled to sustain the rebound seen on Wall St, where a recovery in the energy and tech sectors underpinned most major US indices, but which subsequently closed off their highs on position squaring heading into Thanksgiving. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) traded positive with Australia led by healthcare as Primary Health Care shares outperformed following encouraging updates at its AGM, while sentiment in Japan was turbulent ahead of its long weekend and as financials lagged including MUFG shares on news US prosecutors are investigating the Japanese banking powerhouse. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) failed to hold onto opening gains as the PBoC remained side-lined and refrained from liquidity operations for a 20th consecutive occasion, although downside was stemmed amid trade related hopes after reports US Trade Advisor and known ‘China hawk’ Navarro is to be excluded from the Trump-Xi summit.

FTSE

EX-DIVS: Carnival (CCL LN), DCC (DCC LN), Evraz (EVR LN), Imperial Brands (IMB LN), National Grid (NG/ LN) and Vodafone Group (VOD LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 9.8 points off the FTSE 100

Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN) – UK lawmaker seeks a probe into the way CEO handled information related to one of UK largest ever fraud cases. (Newswires)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – New York’s Department of Financial Services are to end a period of monitoring of Co. at the end of this year after the bank was punished for past failings in compliance control. Separately, Co. are drawing plans to buy back shares, which could be announced alongside FY results and the end of February. (Newswires/FT)

Berkeley Group (BKG LN) – Co. bosses were accused of engaging in years of bribery with a partner at a major estate agent; according to paper filings. (The Guardian)

Royal Mail (RMG LN) – Co. shareholders have demanded answers after the Co. wrote down 85% of the value of recently acquired US delivery businesses “Golden State Overnight” and “Postal Express”, which added doubts over international expansion. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

JUST EAT (JE/ LN) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

FRESNILLO (FRES LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

ROYAL MAIL (RMG LN) UPGRADED TO SECTOR PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT RBC

SPIRAX-SERCO (SPX LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

HALMA (HLMA LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY)/ Volkswagen (VOW3 GY)/ BMW (BMW GY) – US Trump administration have invited the heads of Cos to the White House to discuss US tariffs on carmakers. (Handlesblatt)

Siemens Healthineers (SHL GY) – Q3 final adj. net EUR 1.28bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.40bln. Revenue EUR 13.4bln vs. Prev. EUR 13.7bln. Co. affirms FY18 guidance. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. is pushing a plan to finance a nuclear investment in the UK with claims that it would cut the cost of power from the new reactor to levels competitive with gas and renewable energy. (FT)

Remy Cointreau (RCO FP) – H1 current operating profit +10.1% LFL to EUR 138mln vs. Exp. EUR 132mln. Revenue EUR 571.4mln vs. Prev. EUR 544.4mln. Net EUR 87.5mln vs. Prev. EUR 90.3mln. Cognac division current operating profit +11.3% LFL to EUR 119.5mln. Co. reaffirms FY18 guidance. (Newswires)  

Scor (SCR FP) – Co. announced the creation of a new property and casualty speciality insurance Co. for its clients in the EU. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ADP (ADP FP) UPGRADED TO SECTOR PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT RBC

PAN EUROPE

Telecom Italia (TIT IM)/ Vodafone (VOD LN)/ Swisscom (SCMN SW) – Fines over 28-day billing practices were cancelled by the Italian Court. Fines amounted to EUR 1.16mln for each company. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Italian government plans for value assets to be transferred to a new fixed-line network company with an expected revenue of EUR 5bln per annum and an operating margin of EUR 2bln. Government plans to transfer around 30k Telecom Italia staff to the new company. (Il Messaggero)

Altice (ATC NA) - Reports Q3 Adj. EBITDA down 6.8% at EUR 1.3bln vs Exp. EUR 1.3bln, Q3 revenue down 4.6% to EUR 3.44bln vs Exp. EUR 3.50bln. Says French divisions added 166k broadband customers and 378k postpaid mobile contracts in Q3. Average revenue per customer at EUR 31.7 vs. Prev. EUR 35.9. Sees revenue and Adj. EBITDA growing in 2019 vs. 2018 and confirms full-year guidance. Founder Patrick Drahi says open to sell a stake of his cable network. Executives state they have seen a strong interest for their French fiber network. (Newswires)

UniCredit (UCG IM) – Co. investor Fondazione Cariverona (who owns 1.8% of Co.) said it is the Co.’s job to evaluate options that would create value; according to sources close to the shareholder. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

KPN (KPN NA) DOWNGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM TOP PICK AT RBC

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Co. said its cancer drug, Venclexta, received accelerated approval from the US FDA. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

SWATCH (UHR SW) DOWNGRADED TO SECTOR PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT BARCLAYS

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

NORDEA BANK (NDA SS) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

EQUINOR (EQNR NO) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

US

* SPX +0.3% at 2650, NDX +0.8% at 6576, DJI -0.0% at 24464. SECTORS: Energy +1.6%, Materials +0.8%, Industrials +0.7%, Cons Discretionary +1.0%, Cons Staples -0.8%, Healthcare -0.5%, Financials +0.1%, Tech +0.6%, Telecoms +1.0%, Utilities -1.5%.

subject: Italian Deputy PMs Salvini and Di Maio do not want to negotiate with EU over 2019 budget, while Italian President Mattarella wants PM Conte to reach a deal with European Commission President Juncker over the budget; according to La Repubblica
Italian Deputy PM Di Maio is reportedly ready to negotiate with the EU over budget but does not want to lower expenditures to fund key measures; according to La Stampa
Italian Deputy PM Di Maio opposes cuts in resources for reforms and sees possible budget modifications at parliament
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 22nd November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equities were mixed as the region struggled to sustain the rebound seen on Wall St, where a recovery in the energy and tech sectors underpinned most major US indices
  • UK PM May's spokesperson said PM May and EU's Juncker failed to finalise a deal on terms of Brexit but added that very good progress has been made in talks
  • FX markets were uneventful with the USD subdued as US participants headed into the Thanksgiving holiday
  • Looking ahead, highlights include SARB rate decision, ECB minutes, BoE’s Haldane, Saunders, ECB’s Mersch, supply from Spain and France. US markets closed for Thanksgiving

ASIA

Asian equities were mixed as the region struggled to sustain the rebound seen on Wall St, where a recovery in the energy and tech sectors underpinned most major US indices, but which subsequently closed off their highs on position squaring heading into Thanksgiving. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) traded positive with Australia led by healthcare as Primary Health Care shares outperformed following encouraging updates at its AGM, while sentiment in Japan was turbulent ahead of its long weekend and as financials lagged including MUFG shares on news US prosecutors are investigating the Japanese banking powerhouse. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) failed to hold onto opening gains as the PBoC remained side-lined and refrained from liquidity operations for a 20th consecutive occasion, although downside was stemmed amid trade related hopes after reports US Trade Advisor and known ‘China hawk’ Navarro is to be excluded from the Trump-Xi summit. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet with price action subdued by the choppy risk sentiment and after weaker demand at today’s enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9391 (Prev. 6.9449)

Japanese National CPI (Oct) Y/Y 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)
Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Oct) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)
Japanese National CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Oct) Y/Y Oct 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)


UK/EU

UK PM May's spokesperson said PM May and EU's Juncker failed to finalise a deal on terms of Brexit but added that very good progress has been made in Brexit talks, while PM May is to return to Brussels on Saturday. In related news, Brexit negotiators were reportedly to work through the night to finalise the deal and a Sun reporter suggested if they were successful, there could be a new draft Withdrawal Agreement and Political Declaration published Thursday afternoon. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK Foreign Minister Hunt reportedly warned PM May of the possibility the Brexit deal may be rejected at Parliament and was among the 6 Cabinet ministers that raised serious concern regarding the extent of opposition from within the Tory party to the Brexit deal. In related news, 84 Tory MPs were said to have declared they will not vote for May's Brexit deal according to Tweets by a Buzzfeed reporter. (Telegraph/Twitter)

UK Chancellor Hammond said Brexit backstop is not a good arrangement and smooth Brexit is worth billions of pounds to the UK, while he added that there might not be a Brexit if lawmakers reject the deal and that markets will react negatively if parliament reject the deal. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar proposed a motion requesting the Irish Parliament support draft Brexit agreement. (Newswires)

German Finance Ministry said October tax revenue rose 9.2% Y/Y, while it added that German growth is to continue although not as strong. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets were uneventful with the USD subdued as US participants headed into the Thanksgiving holiday and amid meagre attempts by its major counterparts across the pond to nurse recent losses. In terms of the latest Brexit-related developments, EU's Juncker and UK PM May failed to finalise a deal on terms of Brexit but were said to have made very good progress and PM May will return to Brussels on Saturday, while negotiators were said to work through the night in the hope of finalising an agreement. Elsewhere, AUD/USD and NZD/USD were lacklustre as the rebound in oil prices stalled overnight, while USD/JPY and its related-crosses traded indecisive amid a similar risk tone and inconclusive inflation data from Japan in which all components conformed to expectations.


COMMODITIES

Commodities flatlined overnight with oil prices back below the USD 55.00/bbl level after prices slipped post-settlement as US participants headed into Thanksgiving. Elsewhere, gold and copper were little changed amid an uneventful greenback and with the red metal also restricted by underperformance in its largest consumer China.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (21/Nov): Oil down 3 rigs at 885, gas unchanged at 194, total rigs down 3 at 1079. (Newswires)

CME raised January 2019 (CL F9) oil futures margins to USD 3650 from USD 3550 per contract. (Newswires)

US President Trump tweeted that brutal and extended cold blast could shatter all records. (Newswires)

China is said to be returning to the US crude market as a minimum of 3 very large crude carriers have been booked for late next month. (Platts)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Defence Secretary Mattis said will reduce the scope of military exercise with South Korea to ensure the exercises will not be harmful to diplomatic efforts, while he also commented that it appears Yemen peace talks will take place in early December in Sweden. (Newswires)

Iran Revolutionary Guard commander said US bases and aircraft carriers are within range of Iranian missiles. (Tasnim News)
 

US


Volumes and action were light on Wednesday ahead of Thursday Thanksgiving market holiday. After trading lower in Asia, T-Notes ticked up in European trade, but once again found some sellers around the US open, with dealer positioning ahead of the TIPS supply being cited. The bias was for yield curve narrowing, with 2s5s tightening to levels not seen in 11-years+. The Treasury sold USD 11bln of 10-year TIPS, tailing 0.2bps. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 3+ ticks lower at 119-07+.

subject: EU's Moscovici says the commission is prudent towards Italy
Italian PM Conte to address parliament today and will present urgent report regarding dispute with EU, according to ANSA
Japanese Machine Tool Orders (Oct F) Y/Y -0.7% (Prev. -1.1%)
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia struggled to sustain Wall St rebound, with sentiment mixed heading into holidays
content: Asian equities were mixed as the region struggled to sustain the rebound seen on Wall St, where a recovery in the energy and tech sectors underpinned most major US indices, but which subsequently closed off their highs on position squaring heading into Thanksgiving. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) traded positive with Australia led by healthcare as Primary Health Care shares outperformed following encouraging updates at its AGM, while sentiment in Japan was turbulent ahead of its long weekend and as financials lagged including MUFG shares on news US prosecutors are investigating the Japanese banking powerhouse. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) failed to hold onto opening gains as the PBoC remained side-lined and refrained from liquidity operations for a 20th consecutive occasion, although downside was stemmed amid trade related hopes after reports US Trade Advisor and known ‘China hawk’ Navarro is to be excluded from the Trump-Xi summit. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet with price action subdued by the choppy risk sentiment and after weaker demand at today’s enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia fails to sustain Wall St's rebound, as markets lack solid macro-drivers and with US away for Thanksgiving
content:
Asia equities are mixed as the region struggles to sustain the rebound seen on Wall St, where a recovery in the energy and tech sectors underpinned most major US indices but which subsequently closed off their highs on position squaring heading into Thanksgiving. ASX 200 (+0.6%) is higher with healthcare front running the advances in Australia as Primary Health Care shares outperform following encouraging updates at its AGM, while the Nikkei 225 (Unch) shrugged off early advances and traded flat with weakness seen in financials including MUFG on news US prosecutors are investigating the Japanese banking powerhouse. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) failed to hold onto opening gains as the PBoC remained side-lined and refrained from liquidity operations for a 20th consecutive occasion, but with downside stemmed amid trade related hopes after reports US Trade Advisor and known ‘China hawk’ Navarro is to be excluded from the Trump-Xi summit.

FX markets are quiet with the USD subdued as US participants head into the Thanksgiving holiday season and with the greenback’s major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD attempting to nurse recent losses. In terms of the latest Brexit-related developments, EU's Juncker and UK PM May failed to finalise a deal on terms of Brexit but were said to have made very good progress and PM May will return to Brussels on Saturday, while negotiators were said to work through the night in the hope of finalising an agreement. Elsewhere, AUD/USD and NZD/USD are lacklustre as the rebound in oil prices stalls overnight, while USD/JPY and its related-crosses are indecisive amid a similar risk tone and inconclusive inflation data in which all components conformed to expectations.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are quiet with price action restricted by the choppy risk sentiment and ahead of an enhanced liquidity auction for longer-dated JGBs.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: US has reportedly excluded Trade Advisor Navarro from the Trump-Xi summit
content:
China ZhengTong Auto Services (1728 HK)
- Co. announced a proposed spin-off and listing of its Shanghai Dongzheng Auto business. (Newswires)

HNA Holdings (521 HK)
- Co. is to reduce its stake in Urumqi Airlines to 30% from 70% as it continues with its core divestments. (Nikkei)

New World Development (17 HK)
- Co. makes HKD 1.4bln investment into greater Bay area related to elderly care. (Newswires)

Other News
- WTO are to set up a dispute panel to rule on US complaint against China over IP rights, while China contests US' "false claims" in the IP complaints at WTO meeting; according to a trade official. Furthermore, there were also reports that WTO will proceed with litigation over US steel tariffs, related to retaliation measures after both sides confirmed their wish to litigate. (Newswires)
- US has reportedly excluded US Trade Advisor Navarro from the Trump-Xi summit. (SCMP)
- Shanghai Stock Exchange said it is to only allow listed companies which are planning asset restructuring through share issuances to suspend share trades for a maximum 10 days. (Newswires)
- Chinese Premier Li says will continue and improve policy regarding cross-border e-commerce retail imports. (Newswires)

Data Recap
- China Outstanding Local Government Debt (CNY)(Oct) M/M 18.4T (Prev. 18.3T). (Newswires)
- Macau GDP in Q3 rose 1.6% Y/Y vs. Prev. 6.0% growth in Q2. (Newswires)
